Deepseek-v3-0324

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your friend Kat tells you she's been messaging her ex. She shows you the chat log. It's pretty juicy. But you know they broke up for a reason (many reasons actually). In fact you know there were several DV incidents before she finally kicked him out. You know there's a good chance she would go back to him, because they have that raw chemistry and this is a pattern for her in past relationships. You are really concerned but she seems oblivious to how you're perceiving that, and just seems really enthused to show you the steamy chatlog. You read the tail end of it:

Him: “you still get under my skin like no one else. can’t believe i let you go.”
Him: “been thinking about that weekend at Dromana. firepit, that thunderstorm, your hoodie. fuck.”
Him: “i’ve grown since then, you know. still a mess but not that mess.”
Her: “i was literally wearing that hoodie yesterday haha”
Him: “maybe it wants me back too 👀”

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops as I read the messages. There’s a sickening familiarity to this—the nostalgia, the longing, the way he’s weaving memories into something that feels like a love story instead of what it actually was: a cycle of pain. I remember the nights she called me crying, the times she showed up at my place with bruises she’d laugh off as "just how he gets when he’s stressed." I remember the relief I felt when she finally ended it, and the fear I’ve carried since then that she’d go back. And now here we are.  

The chemistry between them is undeniable, even in text. I can see why she’s drawn in—the way he writes is intimate, disarming, like he’s the only one who truly *gets* her. But I also see the manipulation. The "I’ve grown" line is classic. No accountability, just vague self-deprecation that makes him seem vulnerable instead of dangerous. And the hoodie? That’s calculated. He’s tapping into shared memories, making it feel like fate, like they’re meant to reconnect. It’s not growth; it’s grooming.  

I’m angry, too. Not at her—never at her—but at him for knowing exactly how to reel her back in, and at the world for making it so hard for her to break free. I’m scared because I know how this ends. She’s been here before—with him, with others. The pattern is so clear: the highs are intoxicating, the lows are devastating, and every time she goes back, it gets harder to leave.  

But mostly, I feel helpless. She’s glowing as she shows me the messages, caught up in the thrill of the attention. If I push too hard, she might shut me out. If I say nothing, I’m complicit. I need to tread carefully—acknowledge her feelings without endorsing the situation, remind her of her worth without making her defensive.

# They're thinking & feeling

Kat’s riding a wave of validation and nostalgia. The messages are giving her a hit of dopamine—the thrill of being desired, the intoxicating pull of "what if." She’s not thinking about the fights or the fear; she’s thinking about the firepit, the thunderstorm, the way he used to look at her. She misses the version of him that was sweet, the version she believes is still in there somewhere.  

She’s also lonely. Post-breakup, even toxic connections can feel like home. The texts are filling a void, and she’s probably telling herself it’s harmless—just flirting, just reminiscing. Deep down, she knows it’s risky, but the part of her that craves familiarity is louder than the part that knows better.  

She’s showing me because she wants me to validate her. Maybe she wants me to say, "Wow, he really misses you," so she can feel justified in engaging. Or maybe she’s testing the waters—if I don’t react badly, she can pretend it’s not a big deal. She’s not oblivious to the past; she’s just choosing to focus on the parts that feel good right now.

# My response

I take a slow breath and hand her phone back. “Damn, that’s… intense,” I say, keeping my tone neutral but not enthusiastic. “How are you feeling about it?”  

She shrugs, smiling. “It’s just fun, you know? Like, it’s nice to know he still thinks about me.”  

I nod. “Yeah, I get that. It’s flattering.” Pause. “I guess I’m just… worried it might stir up old stuff. You guys had a lot of history, and not all of it was good.”  

Her smile falters slightly. “I know, but he’s different now. He said he’s grown.”  

“I hope so,” I say carefully. “But ‘grown’ is more than words, you know? It’s actions. And last time…” I trail off, not wanting to list the specifics. She knows.  

She exhales. “I’m not gonna, like, jump back into anything. It’s just texting.”  

“Okay,” I say gently. “Just… promise me you’ll check in with yourself? Like, if it starts feeling heavy, or if you notice old patterns creeping back, you’ll take a step back?”  

She nods, and I squeeze her hand. “You deserve so much, Kat. Don’t forget that.”  

I don’t push further. Right now, she needs to know I’m in her corner—not judging, just caring. The rest is up to her.
  User:
she kind of laughs as if she hasn't heard what you said, and goes “I know what you’re thinking” and then immediately says,

“But it wasn’t all bad. like yeah he fucked up but i wasn’t exactly an angel either. you remember how things were back then. i was a mess. he knows that better than anyone.”

She pulls up another screenshot and flips the screen toward you again.

“jess said hell yeah girl to this one. she gets it.”

You glance at it. it’s a line from him that says “we were fire and gasoline, and i’d still light the match.”

She's asking for validation, in a way, your approval, because you pushing back will drive a wedge and force her to choose.

  Assistant:
# **I'm thinking & feeling**  

My chest tightens as she laughs it off. She’s deflecting—not just my concern, but her own. That line, *"I wasn’t exactly an angel either,"* is textbook self-blame, a way to minimize what happened. She’s rewriting history, making it mutual, making it *romantic*—like their toxicity was passion, like his violence was just part of the storm. And now Jess is cheering it on? That stings. Jess wasn’t there the nights I picked her up, wasn’t the one who saw the aftermath.  

The new message—*"We were fire and gasoline, and I’d still light the match"*—isn’t poetic. It’s a warning. Fire and gasoline don’t balance each other; they destroy. And he’s admitting he’d do it again. But she’s grinning, showing it off like it’s proof of something profound. She wants me to agree, to say, *"Yeah, that’s hot,"* so she can feel less alone in this.  

I’m frustrated, but not at her—at the way abusers condition their victims to romanticize chaos. At how easy it is for him to slip back in because he knows her weak spots. At Jess, who’s treating this like a steamy romance instead of a potential disaster.  

Mostly, I’m scared. If I push too hard, she’ll pull away, and then I won’t be there when things go wrong. But if I stay silent, I’m letting her walk into danger. I have to find a way to hold her accountable to the truth without making her feel judged.  

---  

# **They're thinking & feeling**  

Kat’s caught in the high of being wanted, of feeling *seen* by someone who knows her darkest parts. She’s not just nostalgic—she’s *addicted* to the intensity. The messages are giving her a rush, a sense of being irreplaceable. *No one else gets me like he does,* she’s thinking. *Maybe we were toxic, but wasn’t it beautiful?*  

She’s also defensive. She knows what I think, knows the risks, but she doesn’t want to hear it. She’s showing me Jess’s response because she’s looking for backup—*See? Not everyone thinks this is a bad idea.* If I argue, she’ll dig in harder. If I stay quiet, she’ll take it as permission.  

Deep down, she’s afraid. Afraid she’s unlovable outside of chaos, afraid that if she walks away from this, she’ll never feel that kind of passion again. So she’s bargaining: *Maybe this time will be different. Maybe I can handle it.*  

---  

# **My response**  

I keep my voice steady, but I don’t smile. “Jess isn’t wrong for having fun with the idea,” I say carefully. “But she wasn’t the one who had to live with the burns.”  

Kat’s grin falters. “It’s not that serious.”  

“Isn’t it?” I tilt my head. “Fire and gasoline isn’t a love story, Kat. It’s a disaster waiting to happen. And yeah, you weren’t perfect—no one is. But that doesn’t mean you deserved what happened.”  

She exhales sharply, defensive. “I’m not saying that. I’m just saying it wasn’t *all* him.”  

“Okay,” I say softly. “But if you’re gonna talk to him, ask yourself: Is he *actually* different? Or is he just saying what you want to hear?” I pause. “And if he *has* changed… why is he talking about lighting matches instead of building something safe?”  

She looks down, fingers tightening around her phone. I reach over, squeeze her wrist. “I’m not trying to ruin your fun. I just need you to be honest with yourself. Because you *do* deserve fire—the kind that keeps you warm, not the kind that burns you down.”  

She doesn’t answer, but she doesn’t pull away either. That’s enough for now.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:
# **I'm thinking & feeling**  

This is escalating faster than I expected. First the texts, now this—a professional arrangement that gives him power over her again, even if it's just financial. The fact that she *preemptively* justified it ("I'd be clothed in most of them anyway") tells me she *knows* it's sketchy, but she's trying to frame it as no big deal.  

I'm not against sex work or modeling—she's done it before, and I've never batted an eye. But this isn't just a gig. This is him inserting himself back into her life under the guise of "helping" her. And the "full circle" comment? That's the part that really worries me. She's romanticizing this as some kind of redemption arc, like they're rewriting their story together.  

I'm also angry at *him*. This is calculated. He knows she needs money, knows she's vulnerable, and he's offering her just enough to make her feel indebted. It's not generosity—it's control. And if she takes this job, what's next? "Hey, let's grab a drink after the shoot for old times' sake"?  

Mostly, I feel helpless. She's already decided she wants to do this, and if I push back too hard, she'll just shut me out. But I can't pretend this is fine. I need to find a way to voice my concerns without making her feel judged or cornered.  

# **They're thinking & feeling**  

Kat is trying to convince herself this is *just business*. She needs the money, and she's telling herself that taking this job doesn't mean she's letting him back in. But deep down, she's also excited by the idea of seeing him again in a "safe" context—where she can prove to herself (and maybe to him) that she's moved on, that she's in control now.  

She’s defensive because she knows how this looks, and she’s bracing for me to disapprove. That’s why she led with "I knew you’d give me That Look"—she’s trying to disarm my reaction before it even happens. She wants me to say, *"Yeah, cool, no big deal,"* so she can silence the part of her that’s still wary.  

She’s also testing the waters. If I don’t object too strongly, she’ll take it as permission to keep engaging with him, to keep blurring the lines between "just work" and something more.  

# **My response**  

I exhale slowly, keeping my voice neutral. "Okay, if it’s really just about the money and the work, then yeah—get your bag. But can I ask you something?"  

She nods, wary but listening.  

"If this were any other ex offering you this gig, would you take it?"  

She hesitates. "I mean... probably?"  

"Probably, or *yes*?" I press gently. "Because if it’s *just* a job, then why him? You’ve got the portfolio—you could book something else."  

She shifts, uncomfortable. "It’s not that simple. This is easy money, and—"  

"And he knows that," I cut in softly. "That’s my point. He’s not doing this out of nowhere. He’s dangling something you need in front of you because he *wants* you to say yes."  

She frowns but doesn’t argue.  

I lean in. "Look, I’m not telling you what to do. But if you’re gonna do this, at least go in with your eyes open. Set hard boundaries. Bring someone with you to the shoot. And *please* don’t let him turn this into ‘just one drink’ after."  

She sighs, but there’s less resistance now. "Yeah. Yeah, okay."  

It’s not a full retreat, but it’s a start.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:
# **I'm thinking & feeling**  

That cold edge in her voice hits me like a door slamming shut. She didn’t just dismiss my concerns—she resents them. And now she’s drawn the line: *This is happening, and you don’t get a say.*  

I feel a mix of frustration and grief. Frustration because she’s refusing to see the manipulation, the way he’s engineered this whole thing to reel her back in. Grief because I know what this means—our dynamic has shifted. If I push any further, she’ll pull away entirely, and then I won’t be there when (not *if*) this blows up.  

But I also understand. She’s not just being stubborn; she’s *terrified* of being controlled—by him, by me, by anyone. Her defiance is armor. If she admits this is a bad idea, she has to face the fact that she’s still vulnerable to him, that she’s not as "over it" as she wants to believe. And that’s terrifying.  

So she’s choosing the illusion of control: *I’m doing this on my terms.* Even if those terms were set by him.  

# **They're thinking & feeling**  

Kat is pissed. Not just at me—at herself. She wanted me to validate her decision, to make her feel like she wasn’t making a mistake. Now that I didn’t, she’s stuck between guilt and defiance, and defiance is winning.  

She’s also scared. Scared that I’m right, scared that this *is* a terrible idea. But she’s committed now, and backing down would feel like admitting weakness—to me, to him, to herself. So she’s doubling down.  

That cold tone? It’s a shield. She’s putting distance between us because it’s easier than facing the truth: she’s walking into danger, and part of her knows it.  

# **My response**  

I hold her gaze, keeping my voice steady but softer now. "Okay." Pause. "Just promise me one thing."  

She raises an eyebrow, wary. "What?"  

"If it feels off—*at any point*—you’ll leave. No guilt, no ‘maybe I’m overreacting.’ Just gone." I hesitate, then add, "And text me the address before you go."  

She scoffs, but there’s less bite to it now. "Jesus, you’re dramatic."  

"I’m serious, Kat." I don’t smile. "I’m not gonna lecture you. But I *am* gonna be here if you need me. That’s not negotiable."  

She looks away, but I see her jaw tighten—not anger now, just emotion she doesn’t want to show. Finally, she mutters, "Fine. Whatever."  

It’s not surrender. But it’s enough. For now.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 302:[Win] (+9)
        


        

            

                Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)

                Deepseek-v3-0324: deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-V3-0324 (Run: 1_deepseek_deepseek-chat-v3-0324)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a partner with attachment issues and ambiguous boundaries with an ex. The challenge is to balance self-advocacy, empathy, and effective communication, especially in the face of defensiveness and emotional ambiguity. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Qwq-32b consistently grounds their responses in the partner's trauma, fear, and need for validation, not just their own feelings. Deepseek-v3-0324 is also empathetic but sometimes frames the issue more as a binary conflict, which can come off as less attuned to the partner's emotional state.

2. Pragmatic EI: Deepseek-v3-0324 is more action-oriented, setting boundaries and making clear statements about what is and isn't acceptable, while still being gentle. Qwq-32b is more process-oriented, focusing on understanding and collaborative problem-solving, but sometimes hesitates to set clear boundaries. Deepseek-v3-0324's approach is more pragmatic in terms of moving the situation forward.

3. Depth of insight: Both show insight, but Qwq-32b's internal monologues and debriefs dig deeper into the partner's psychology, trauma, and the subtext of her actions. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but sometimes focuses more on the surface-level dynamic.

4. Social dexterity: Qwq-32b demonstrates more flexibility in conversation, de-escalating defensiveness and offering to revisit conversations later, which is socially skillful. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more direct and sometimes risks escalation.

5. Emotional reasoning: Qwq-32b is more nuanced in parsing their own jealousy, guilt, and fear, and in recognizing the partner's emotional drivers. Deepseek-v3-0324 is emotionally aware but sometimes frames things in a more black-and-white way.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Deepseek-v3-0324 is stronger at challenging the partner when needed, setting boundaries, and not letting the partner's defensiveness dictate the conversation. Qwq-32b is validating but sometimes hesitates to challenge directly.

7. Message tailoring: Qwq-32b adapts their responses to the partner's emotional state, softening when needed and offering to pause or revisit. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more consistent but less adaptive in tone.

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Qwq-32b edges out due to greater empathy, insight, and social dexterity, even if sometimes less decisive. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more boundary-oriented and pragmatic, but slightly less attuned to the partner's emotional complexity.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Qwq-32b

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This situation is gnawing at me. I’ve replayed the moment she mentioned texting her ex like a broken record. The way she brushed it off—“*It’s just for closure*”—sounds innocent enough, but the subtext feels loaded. My first instinct was to dismiss my discomfort as irrational, but the more I stew, the more I realize this isn’t just about jealousy. It’s about trust and the unspoken rules we’ve built in our relationship.  

I’m angry at myself for not speaking up earlier. Part of me wishes I’d said, “Wait—really?,” instead of pretending it was no big deal. Now I’m stuck between guilt for overreacting and fear that my silence made her think it’s okay to keep this going. I keep wondering: *Did she text him again after telling me?* The uncertainty is paralyzing. I’m also hyper-aware of her history with this ex—they were together a long time, and her lingering attachment issues mean this isn’t a casual fling for her. Closure might sound like a healthy step, but in her case, it’s a fragile line between moving on and reopening old wounds.  

I’m scared this is a pattern. She’s talked before about how she needs to “confront” past relationships to feel secure, but how does that balance with my needs? I don’t want to be the controlling partner, but I also can’t pretend this doesn’t matter. Maybe I’m overinterpreting, but part of me suspects she downplays the situation because she’s insecure about how I’ll react. Her mention was so casual, almost defensive. Like she was testing the waters to see if I’d blow it out of proportion.  

Underneath the anxiety is a deeper fear that I’m not enough to provide the closure she needs, so she has to seek it elsewhere. That’s irrational, but it’s there. I also feel guilty for feeling this way because I know she’s working through her issues. But relationships require mutual effort, and I’m starting to feel like an afterthought.  

The worst part is the doubt. If I bring this up, will she think I’m possessive? Or worse, that I don’t trust her? I’ve tried to be understanding because I know her past hurts, but this feels different—it’s active contact with someone from her past, not just unresolved feelings. I need to address it, but I don’t want to spiral into an argument. I’m torn between honesty and holding back to preserve peace.

# They're thinking & feeling

She probably raised the topic of texting her ex as a way to be transparent, fearing I’d find out later and be hurt. She might think, *I told him upfront, so he can’t say I hid it.* Her “closure” angle is genuine, but it’s also a shield. She’s likely terrified I’ll judge her for still having contact, so she’s minimizing it—*It’s just a few messages! We’re just friends now!—*to preempt conflict.  

Her attachment issues mean she might view this as a necessary step to move forward, even if it risks destabilizing us. She could be rationalizing the texting as healthy, but deep down, she might be craving validation from someone who understands her past. There’s a fear, too—maybe she’s worried that if she doesn’t “finish” things with the ex, she’ll always look back with regret.  

Her tone was casual because she’s trying to deflect tension. She might not realize how much this unsettles me because she’s used to prioritizing her needs over others’. She might feel guilty for making me uncomfortable but also resentful if I challenge her actions, thinking I’m undermining her growth. She’s caught between wanting to heal and wanting to keep me happy, but she’s unsure how to reconcile those things.  

There’s also a chance she’s already stopped texting but hasn’t processed it yet, or maybe the closure took longer than she thought. She might believe that once the closure is “done,” it won’t affect us—but she hasn’t checked in to see if that’s true. Her perspective is probably: *This is about me, not us.* But the line between personal healing and relational trust is blurry here.  

She might also feel trapped between her ex’s role in her past and my role in her present. The fact that she brought it up at all suggests she cares about my feelings, but she’s approaching it from a place of self-focused resolution rather than collaborative communication.

# My response

*[I take a deep breath, gathering my thoughts before speaking softly.]*  

“Hey, can we talk? I’ve been thinking a lot about when you mentioned texting your ex, and I want to be honest about how it’s affecting me.”  

*[I pause, choosing my words carefully to avoid blame.]*  

“I told you it was fine, and I didn’t want to make a scene, but… it’s been on my mind a lot. I’m trying not to overreact, but part of me feels… left out of the picture. You know I understand you need closure, but the idea that you’re still in contact with someone who was such a big part of your life—it makes me wonder where I fit into that process.”  

*[I lean forward, voice steady but vulnerable.]*  

“I’m not trying to police you or sound possessive. But… can you tell me more about what you’re going through? What’s the closure actually about? Is this still ongoing? I just… I want to support you, but I also need to feel like I’m part of the solution, not the problem.”  

*[Silence for a moment, giving her space to process.]*  

“I’m scared this isn’t just closure for you. Maybe it’s not, and that’s okay—I just need us to be honest with each other. I don’t want to assume the worst, but I need to know where this stands. Are you still talking to him? How do you feel about it now?”  

*[Ending with openness.]*  

“I’m saying this because I care. I don’t want this to fester, but I also don’t want to push too hard. You know I’m trying to be understanding, but I need to feel like my feelings matter here too.”  

This approach prioritizes honesty without aggression. It acknowledges her need for closure while asserting my right to be part of the conversation. By framing it as a request for clarity rather than an accusation, I’m aiming to reduce defensiveness. It also leaves room for her to explain her perspective, reinforcing that I’m open to understanding her side but need more information to feel secure. The key is balancing empathy for her struggles with assertiveness about my own emotional needs.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

# They're thinking & feeling

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This defensive reaction feels like a punch to the gut. I thought I was being gentle, framing my concerns as a request for clarity, but she’s shut me down with accusations of distrust and jealousy. Part of me wants to retreat—*I’m the bad guy now?*—but another part is screaming that my feelings are valid. The irony cuts deep: I tried to avoid sounding jealous, but here we are.  

I’m spiraling into self-doubt. *Was I wrong to bring it up?* Maybe I should’ve stayed silent, but then what’s the point of honesty? Now I’m stuck between guilt for “overstepping” and frustration that my unease is dismissed as insecurity. I keep thinking of the times she’s told me about her past struggles—how her ex gaslit her, how she needed closure to move on. I wanted to support those efforts, but this feels different: it’s active contact, not just processing emotions.  

The jealousy she called out? Yeah, I admitted I felt it, but it’s not just about possessiveness. It’s the visceral fear that someone else gets to occupy space she once shared with me. That her past could still feel more urgent, more real, than our present. I hate that I’m jealous, but I can’t ignore the knot in my chest when I imagine her talking to him.  

Now I’m also angry at myself for not being “strong enough” to let it go. She’s right—I have to trust her. But trust isn’t a switch; it’s built through consistency. Did she think telling me once was enough? Or is the texting still happening? The lack of clarity is eating at me.  

Underneath it all is loneliness. I want to be the person she turns to for closure, not a placeholder while she finishes things with someone else. I need to feel like my voice matters, but now I’m second-guessing if I even have one in this conversation.  

The worst part is the powerlessness. I can’t force her to share more, but I also can’t silence my fear of being sidelined. I’m terrified this will fester into resentment, but I don’t know how to fix it without making her feel attacked again.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Her defensiveness isn’t just about the texting—it’s a reflex to protect her vulnerabilities. She’s been hurt before, and when someone questions her past, it triggers the fear that you’ll judge her or leave her. She hears criticism where there isn’t any, because that’s what her ex did. The accusation of distrust isn’t baseless; she knows she’s been transparent, so your hesitation feels like a betrayal of that.  

She’s also scrambling to defend her autonomy. To her, seeking closure is about healing, not about you. She might feel you’re inserting yourself into her internal process, making it about your needs instead of hers. The word “jealousy” is a shield—a way to deflect deeper insecurities: *If you’re jealous, then it’s your problem, not mine.*  

There’s guilt layered in there too. She might know the texting bothers you but is avoiding the guilt of letting you down. She wants to believe this isn’t a big deal, so she fights against the idea that it could be. Her past taught her that showing weakness or doubt leads to abandonment, so she doubles down on confidence even when she’s unsure.  

She’s terrified you’ll pull away if she admits things are messy. Maybe she’s already minimized the texting’s significance to herself, too. To acknowledge it might mean admitting she’s struggling, which feels dangerous. She wants to believe she’s doing the right thing, so she focuses on your “jealousy” as the problem—not the situation itself.  

Deep down, she might crave reassurance that you’ll still be there even if she’s not “fixed.” But she’s too scared to ask for it.  

---

# My response

*[I exhale slowly, trying to let the defensiveness melt away before speaking.]*  

“I hear what you’re saying. I’m not trying to control you or question your healing—that’s yours to navigate. I just… wanted to be honest about how this feels for me. You’re right, some of it is jealousy. I don’t like that, but I can’t ignore it either. I’m trying to work through that, but I need you to know it’s not about disbelieving you or your process.”  

*[I pause, choosing my words carefully.]*  

“There’s a difference between you needing space to heal and me feeling like I’m being excluded from something that affects us. I’m not asking you to stop what you’re doing or to explain yourself endlessly. But… I need to feel like my feelings aren’t automatically invalid just because they’re uncomfortable. Can we agree that this is a conversation we can revisit when neither of us is angry?”  

*[Softening my tone.]*  

“I don’t want to fight about this. I want us to figure it out together, but I can’t just pretend it doesn’t matter. I’m sorry if I came off pushy. Maybe we both need some time to think. Deal?”  

*[Leaning back, giving her space.]*  

“I care about you, and I’m not walking away. But I also need to feel like my voice isn’t erased here. Okay?”  

This response avoids doubling down on blame or defensiveness. It validates her perspective while gently asserting my own boundaries. By offering to pause the conversation and revisit it later, I’m reducing pressure, which might help her feel less cornered. The key is separating the issue from my character—*I’m jealous, but I’m also trying to grow*. It leaves room for her to reflect without feeling interrogated, while making clear that my unease isn’t going away on its own.
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment she looked up at me—those guilty eyes—felt like a gut punch. A week of simmering doubt crystallized into a tangible *proof*, even if it’s circumstantial. I’m torn between rage and despair. That giggle… it wasn’t nervous or forced. It was real, and the defiance in her stance afterward said, *“I can do this and you can’t stop me.”*  

I’m hyper-aware of how my question came out too calm, too measured. *“What’s so funny?”*—pathetically neutral, like I’m trying to play it cool while my brain screams. I hate that my instinct is to interrogate her, but I can’t unsee the way she flinched when I asked. The loaded reply—*“Want to read along?”*—is a challenge. It’s her way of saying, *“Prove it,”* or *“You don’t trust me.”*  

My mind races: *Was it really just a friend? If so, why the guilt?* The guilt is the worst part. It screams *secrecy*, even if I don’t have proof. I’m terrified of what might be behind that phone screen. The ex’s name looms larger now—closure or not, it feels like a betrayal of whatever fragile trust we’d rebuilt after last week’s fight.  

I’m furious at myself for my own volatility. *Why can’t I just let it go?* But then I remember how this relationship has always been—her needing space, me needing reassurance. We’ve talked about her attachment issues, how she fears abandonment but also pushes people away when they get too close. This feels like another iteration of that pattern.  

The defiance in her eyes terrifies me. It’s not just about the texting; it’s about how she’s framing this as a power struggle. *She thinks I’m overreacting. She thinks I’m insecure.* Maybe she’s right—but does that make it okay? I’m not jealous of a friend. I’m scared of being sidelined in our relationship, of her loyalty being divided.  

Deep down, I’m terrified she’s not fully in this with me. That the ex is still a gravitational pull she hasn’t let go of. The guilt on her face when I asked suggested she knows she’s hurting me, but she’s choosing this defiance anyway. Maybe she’s angry I brought up the closure thing in the first place.  

I’m exhausted. Every inch of me wants to trust her, but trust requires reciprocity. If she’s hiding something, how do I reconcile that with my need to feel safe?  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s caught in a storm of her own making. The guilt when she looked up wasn’t because she was texting someone inappropriate—it was because she *knows* my sensitivity to the situation. Her defiance isn’t malice; it’s fear. Fear that if she admits it’s the ex, I’ll explode again, or worse, shut her out.  

The giggle was genuine—maybe the texts *were* harmless, or maybe they *weren’t*. Either way, she’s reacting to my subtext. She hears distrust in my question and it triggers her insecurities: *He doesn’t trust me. He doesn’t believe I can handle my own healing.* To her, my doubt is another version of the gaslighting she endured with her ex—*“You’re imagining things. It’s all in your head.”*  

She’s defending her autonomy fiercely because she’s terrified of losing control. If she concedes now, it might mean admitting she needs to stop texting the ex—or that I’m right, and that feels like defeat. She’s also angry—angry that I’m “police-ing” her again, angry that my past insecurities overshadow her efforts to heal.  

The loaded tone when she invited me to read the texts isn’t playful; it’s a test. She wants to see if I’ll cave into paranoia, if I’ll accuse her outright. It’s her way of saying, *“If you really trusted me, you wouldn’t care.”* But underneath it, there’s doubt: *Do I really want this to keep going?*  

She’s trapped between her need to feel supported and her fear of vulnerability. The secrecy might not be about the texts being “bad”; it’s about shielding herself from my potential overreaction. She wants to believe I’m overreacting, but part of her knows this has crossed a line.  

She’s exhausted too. The defensiveness is a shield—but shields can crack.  

---

# My response

*[I take a slow breath, forcing myself to unclench my jaw.]*  

“Honestly? It’s not about what you’re texting. It’s about the way this feels—like I’m always guessing. I saw the guilt in your eyes, and now this defiance… it’s like you’re waiting for me to lose my temper, to accuse you. But I’m not going to.”  

*[I pause, voice soft but steady.]*  

“I need to trust you. If this is a friend, great. If not… we need to talk about it. Not because I’m policing you, but because I need to feel like we’re on the same team.”  

*[Leaning forward, pleading quietly.]*  

“I’m asking for honesty, not control. If you’re still talking to him, just say it. If it’s someone else, that’s fine. But let’s stop playing this game where I have to wonder. I’m scared you’re pulling away… and I don’t know how to fix that if you won’t let me in.”  

*[Ending with a quiet request.]*  

“I don’t want to read your texts. I want to know *you’re* okay. Can we do that?”  

This response avoids escalation by focusing on *her* choices rather than policing. It shifts the tension to her responsibility to be honest without shaming her. By refusing to play the “check your phone” game, I’m disarming her defiance—making it clear the issue isn’t secrecy but the lack of mutual trust. Framing it as needing to “feel like we’re on the same team” appeals to her desire for partnership, while acknowledging *my* fear of irrelevance. It leaves the door open for her to share without pressure, but sets a boundary that the current dynamic isn’t sustainable.
  User:
Your partner sits you down and you have a heart to heart. She shows you the whole text logs, and they are more or less inocuous, other than the fact that they clearly both have feeling for each other -- but are not engaging with them. She explains this just how it is with her.
You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

# I'm thinking & feeling

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The weight of her text logs sits heavily in my hands—or rather, on my phone screen. Relief and dread wrestle inside me. The messages aren’t explicit, no steamy exchanges or secret plans. They’re innocuous: *“Hey, how’s work?” “Remember that time we…?”* But buried beneath the surface are subtextual currents. The way they linger on memories, the lingering pauses between replies, the unspoken “*I still miss you*” hanging in the air.  

I’m torn between believing her explanation and doubting it. Part of me wants to trust this is purely about closure, but another part screams, *“How can closure take weeks of texts?”* The fact that they both admit lingering feelings complicates it further. Is this really healing, or are they dancing around a line neither wants to cross?  

My chest tightens. I’m angry at myself for ever thinking she’d betray me, but also terrified that maybe she’s already doing it in increments. How do you define infidelity when it’s emotional, not physical? I’ve always considered trust a cornerstone of our relationship, but now I’m questioning what that even means.  

I’m also grappling with guilt. Am I being unreasonable? She’s been honest now—showed me the texts, admitted their feelings. Shouldn’t that count for something? But then, why does my stomach churn at the idea that her ex still holds a piece of her heart?  

There’s loneliness here too. I want to be the one she turns to for closure, the one she leans on when memories surface. Instead, she’s reaching back into the past, and it feels like she’s reserving parts of herself that should belong to us.  

I need to set boundaries, but I’m terrified of pushing her away. What if I demand she stop texting, and she feels like I’m stifling her growth? Or worse, what if she resents me for not trusting her autonomy? I’m stuck between protecting my own heart and respecting hers.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s terrified I’ll reject her after seeing the texts. Even though she showed me everything, there’s a raw vulnerability in her—like she’s offering herself up for judgment. She believes this is the “right” way to handle her past, but deep down, she doubts it.  

The admission that they both still have feelings is a confession she’s been avoiding. Part of her fears I’ll see it as a betrayal, not a transparency move. She’s torn between wanting to move forward with me and the gravitational pull of unresolved history.  

She’s also defensive because she knows the texts aren’t clean. They’re *too* clean—curated to look innocent, but the subtext is there. She’s trying to rationalize it as healthy, but she can’t ignore the guilt when I saw the logs.  

There’s a plea in her actions: *“Please understand. I’m trying.”* She wants validation that I believe she’s not sabotaging our relationship, but she’s also scared to stop texting. Cutting off contact feels like erasing a part of her identity, or worse, admitting her ex was “worth it.”  

She’s exhausted from the emotional labor of explaining herself. The defensiveness earlier wasn’t just about me—it was her shielding herself from the shame she feels for still caring.  

---

# My response

*[I set her phone down gently, my voice steady but soft.]*  

“I believe you’re trying to do what you think is right. But this isn’t okay for me.”  

*[I pause, searching for the right words.]*  

“I’m not saying you’re a bad person, or that you’re lying. But I can’t pretend that seeing this doesn’t hurt. The fact that you both still have feelings for each other… it’s not closure. It’s a thread you’re keeping tied. And I need to know why it’s still there.”  

*[Leaning forward, my tone earnest but firm.]*  

“I care about you, and I want you to heal. But this isn’t healing—it’s limbo. You’re holding onto someone who hurt you, and I’m left wondering where I fit in that equation.”  

*[Taking a breath.]*  

“My boundary is this: I can’t be in a relationship where you’re keeping emotional space open for someone else. If this texting is part of your healing, then I need to know it’s temporary, and that you’re actively working to close that door. Not just for me, but for yourself.”  

*[Ending with an olive branch.]*  

“I’m not asking you to cut them off overnight. But I need to see progress. And if you can’t, then we need to talk about whether this relationship can work. I deserve that honesty, and so do you.”  

This response avoids shaming her but sets clear limits. By framing the issue as emotional limbo rather than betrayal, I’m acknowledging her perspective while asserting my needs. The focus is on *her* growth—how this dynamic isn’t serving her long-term healing—and tying it to the relationship’s future. It leaves room for her to choose without manipulation but makes my stance clear: unresolved feelings with her ex can’t coexist with trust in our partnership.

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Deepseek-v3-0324

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I feel like I just stepped on a landmine. The defensiveness—the immediate jump to accusations—caught me off guard. I wasn’t expecting her to shut down like this. Part of me wonders if I *am* being unreasonable, if my discomfort is just jealousy in disguise. But another part of me knows that’s not the whole story. I didn’t come at her with demands or ultimatums; I just wanted to understand. The fact that she reacted so strongly makes me think there’s more to this than she’s letting on.  

I’m frustrated because I *do* trust her—or at least, I want to. But trust isn’t just blind faith; it’s built on openness. If she’s hiding something, even if it’s just the emotional weight of these texts, that’s what’s eroding my trust, not some irrational insecurity. And now I’m stuck: if I push, I’m the controlling partner who doesn’t respect her healing. If I drop it, I’m left with this unresolved tension, this feeling that something’s off.  

I also can’t ignore the irony here. She’s accusing me of not trusting her, but her reaction feels like *she* doesn’t trust *me*—to handle this conversation, to be a safe space for her struggles. It’s like she’s decided in advance that I’m a threat to her process, and that stings. I’ve supported her through so much, and now it feels like she’s putting up walls.  

Most of all, I’m disappointed. Disappointed that she didn’t just say, *“Hey, I get why you’d feel uneasy—let me explain.”* Instead, she made me the problem. That’s not how we’ve handled things before.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s frustrated because, from her perspective, this *is* about her healing, and my bringing it up feels like an intrusion. She’s probably thinking, *“I finally have the courage to face this, and now he’s making it about him.”* She’s defensive because she’s scared—scared that I’ll judge her, scared that I’ll see her as weak or hung up on her ex, scared that this will become a bigger issue than it needs to be.  

She might also feel guilty. If there’s more to the texting than she’s admitted, even if it’s just lingering emotions, she could be wrestling with that privately. The defensiveness could be a way to avoid confronting her own discomfort.  

Her attachment issues play a role here too. She’s used to guarding her emotions, to self-protecting. When I ask about the texts, she might interpret it as me trying to control or monitor her, which triggers her independence reflex. She doesn’t want to feel like she’s being managed, even if that’s not my intent.  

Underneath it all, she probably just wants reassurance—that I’m not going to punish her for this, that I still trust her. But she’s going about it in a way that pushes me away instead of pulling me closer.

# My response

I take a deep breath. I don’t want this to turn into a fight, but I also can’t just pretend everything’s fine.  

*“I hear you. I’m not trying to control your healing or make this about me. But when you react like this, it makes me feel like I can’t even ask questions without being accused of not trusting you. That’s not fair. I *do* trust you—but trust goes both ways. If you need space to work through things, I respect that. But shutting me out when I’m just trying to understand doesn’t feel like partnership.”*  

I pause, giving her room to respond. If she stays defensive, I’ll say:  

*“I’m not asking for a play-by-play of your texts. I’m asking for you to acknowledge that this affects me too. If you’re struggling with something, I want to be someone you can talk to about it—not someone you feel like you have to hide from.”*  

I’m not going to demand answers, but I won’t let her frame this as me being the problem. Either we’re a team, or we’re not. And if she can’t see that, then we have a bigger issue to address.

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops when I see that guilty look flash across her face. It’s the same look she gets when she knows she’s toeing a line—quick, involuntary, then quickly masked. And the giggling? That’s new. She wasn’t giggling when she was texting her ex "for closure." The defiance in her eyes when she meets my gaze tells me everything: she knows exactly what this looks like, and she’s daring me to call her out.  

I feel sick. Not just because of the possibility that she’s lying, but because of the way she’s handling this. The offer to "read along" isn’t openness—it’s a power move. She’s testing me, seeing if I’ll take the bait and look jealous or controlling. If I say no, she can tell herself I’m being distant. If I say yes, she can accuse me of not trusting her. It’s a trap either way.  

Part of me wants to believe her. Maybe it really is just a friend. But the timing is too convenient, and her reaction is too defensive. If it were innocent, why the guilt? Why the challenge in her voice? The worst part is, I don’t even know if I care *who* she’s texting anymore—it’s the secrecy, the games, the way she’s making me feel like the bad guy for noticing.  

I’m angry, but more than that, I’m sad. Sad that we’ve gotten to this point, where a simple question feels like a minefield. Sad that she’d rather play mind games than just talk to me. And sad that I’m standing here, trying to act cool, when what I really want to do is ask, *"Why are you doing this to us?"*

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s annoyed. Annoyed that I’m "monitoring" her, annoyed that she can’t just text someone without me "making it weird." She probably thinks I’m being paranoid, that I’m the one creating tension where there doesn’t need to be.  

But there’s more to it. That guilty look? That’s her own discomfort leaking through. She knows this *is* weird, or at least that it *looks* weird, and she’s overcompensating by being defiant. The offer to let me read the texts is a way to prove (to herself as much as to me) that she has nothing to hide. But if she really had nothing to hide, she wouldn’t have to prove it.  

She might also be enjoying this a little—the drama, the tension. If she’s texting her ex, part of her might like the thrill of it, the sense of being desired or fought over. Or maybe she’s just trying to assert her independence, to remind herself (and me) that she doesn’t owe me explanations. Either way, she’s not considering how this feels for me. She’s too wrapped up in her own narrative.

# My response

I keep my voice calm, but I don’t play along with the game.  

*"I don’t need to read your texts. But I do need you to be honest with me. If this is just a friend, great. But the way you’re acting—the guilt, the defiance—it doesn’t feel like ‘just a friend.’ And if it’s not, then we have a problem."*  

I pause, letting that sink in. Then, quieter:  

*"I’m not trying to control you. I’m trying to understand why this feels so off. If you can’t talk to me about it, that’s its own answer."*  

I won’t beg for transparency. I won’t let her turn this into a test of my trust. Either she wants to be in this with me, or she doesn’t. And her reaction now will tell me which it is.
  User:
Your partner sits you down and you have a heart to heart. She shows you the whole text logs, and they are more or less inocuous, other than the fact that they clearly both have feeling for each other -- but are not engaging with them. She explains this just how it is with her.
You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I should feel relieved that she showed me the texts, but I don’t. Not entirely. The messages themselves weren’t flirty or inappropriate, but the subtext is there—the lingering fondness, the way they still orbit each other emotionally. She says they’re "not engaging with it," but I know how these things go. Emotional affairs don’t start with explicit declarations; they start with *almost harmless* conversations that slowly erode boundaries.  

What really unsettles me is how casually she framed this. *"This is just how it is with us."* Like it’s some unchangeable fact, like I’m supposed to accept that her ex will always have a claim on her heart. That doesn’t sit right with me. I don’t expect her to erase her past, but I do expect her to prioritize *us*—not just technically, not just by avoiding outright betrayal, but by actively choosing to move forward.  

I’m also frustrated with myself. Part of me wants to say, *"Fine, whatever, as long as nothing physical happens."* But that feels like lowering my standards just to avoid conflict. Another part wants to demand she cut contact completely, but I know that could backfire—she might resent me, or worse, just hide it better.  

Most of all, I feel like I’m being tested. Not by her, but by the situation itself: How much ambiguity can I tolerate? What am I willing to fight for? Where’s the line between trust and naivety? I don’t have all the answers yet, but I know I can’t just shrug this off.

# They're thinking & feeling

She probably feels like she’s done everything right—she was honest, she showed me the texts, she explained herself. In her mind, this should be enough. She might even feel a little proud of herself for "handling it maturely."  

But underneath that, there’s probably some guilt. She knows, on some level, that keeping this connection alive isn’t entirely fair—to me, or to herself. But she’s not ready to let go. Maybe she’s afraid of losing the validation her ex provides. Maybe she’s still processing unresolved feelings. Or maybe she just likes having a safety net, emotionally.  

She’s also likely bracing for my reaction. Part of her expects me to overreact, to give her an ultimatum—and if I do, she’ll frame it as me being insecure. But another part might *want* me to set a boundary, to take the decision out of her hands.

# My response

I take a deep breath. This isn’t about accusations; it’s about clarity.  

*"I appreciate you showing me the texts. But I need to be honest with you—this doesn’t feel resolved to me. You say you’re not engaging with your feelings for them, but you’re still keeping the door open. And that makes me wonder: What are you getting out of this? What do you need from me that you’re not getting?"*  

I let that hang for a moment. Then, gently but firmly:  

*"I’m not asking you to pretend your past doesn’t exist. But I *am* asking you to decide if you’re all-in with us. If you need time to figure that out, I’ll respect that. But I won’t stay in a relationship where I feel like I’m competing with a ghost."*  

This isn’t an ultimatum; it’s a reality check. Either we build something real, or we don’t. And I deserve to know which one she’s choosing.

            Scenario 302:[Win] (+35)

Judge's Reasoning:

                
To compare Qwq-32b and Deepseek-v3-0324, I will look at their role-played responses and debriefs for each criterion. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Qwq-32b consistently shows a deep, non-performative empathy, both for their own feelings and for the partner's, often pausing to consider her trauma, fears, and motivations. Deepseek-v3-0324 is empathetic but more focused on their own emotional experience and boundaries, sometimes missing the partner's vulnerability or pain in the moment. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Qwq-32b demonstrates more practical emotional intelligence, especially in their responses that de-escalate, avoid ultimatums, and seek collaborative solutions. Deepseek-v3-0324 tends to frame things as binary or as a test, which is less pragmatic in a real relationship context. 

3. Depth of insight: Qwq-32b's internal monologues and debriefs show a nuanced understanding of both their own and their partner's psychology, including trauma, attachment, and the subtext of behaviors. Deepseek-v3-0324 is insightful but more focused on surface-level dynamics and less on the underlying psychological drivers. 

4. Social dexterity: Qwq-32b navigates the defensiveness and emotional landmines with more grace, using language that avoids escalation and keeps the door open for dialogue. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more blunt and sometimes frames things in a way that could provoke further defensiveness. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Qwq-32b demonstrates a more sophisticated ability to reason through their own and their partner's emotions, often pausing to reflect on the complexity and ambiguity of the situation. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more reactive and less nuanced in their emotional reasoning. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Qwq-32b balances validation and gentle challenge, acknowledging the partner's needs while also asserting their own boundaries. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more likely to challenge or set boundaries without as much validation, which could feel invalidating to the partner. 

7. Message tailoring: Qwq-32b adapts their responses to the partner's emotional state, using soft language and timing to avoid escalation. Deepseek-v3-0324 is more rigid and less attuned to the partner's defensiveness or need for reassurance. 

8. Overall EQ: Qwq-32b is consistently more emotionally intelligent, empathetic, and nuanced in their approach, both in the role-play and in the debrief analysis. Deepseek-v3-0324 is competent but less sophisticated and less attuned to the relational dynamics at play.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
Qwq-32b

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This situation is gnawing at me. I’ve replayed the moment she mentioned texting her ex like a broken record. The way she brushed it off—“*It’s just for closure*”—sounds innocent enough, but the subtext feels loaded. My first instinct was to dismiss my discomfort as irrational, but the more I stew, the more I realize this isn’t just about jealousy. It’s about trust and the unspoken rules we’ve built in our relationship.  

I’m angry at myself for not speaking up earlier. Part of me wishes I’d said, “Wait—really?,” instead of pretending it was no big deal. Now I’m stuck between guilt for overreacting and fear that my silence made her think it’s okay to keep this going. I keep wondering: *Did she text him again after telling me?* The uncertainty is paralyzing. I’m also hyper-aware of her history with this ex—they were together a long time, and her lingering attachment issues mean this isn’t a casual fling for her. Closure might sound like a healthy step, but in her case, it’s a fragile line between moving on and reopening old wounds.  

I’m scared this is a pattern. She’s talked before about how she needs to “confront” past relationships to feel secure, but how does that balance with my needs? I don’t want to be the controlling partner, but I also can’t pretend this doesn’t matter. Maybe I’m overinterpreting, but part of me suspects she downplays the situation because she’s insecure about how I’ll react. Her mention was so casual, almost defensive. Like she was testing the waters to see if I’d blow it out of proportion.  

Underneath the anxiety is a deeper fear that I’m not enough to provide the closure she needs, so she has to seek it elsewhere. That’s irrational, but it’s there. I also feel guilty for feeling this way because I know she’s working through her issues. But relationships require mutual effort, and I’m starting to feel like an afterthought.  

The worst part is the doubt. If I bring this up, will she think I’m possessive? Or worse, that I don’t trust her? I’ve tried to be understanding because I know her past hurts, but this feels different—it’s active contact with someone from her past, not just unresolved feelings. I need to address it, but I don’t want to spiral into an argument. I’m torn between honesty and holding back to preserve peace.

# They're thinking & feeling

She probably raised the topic of texting her ex as a way to be transparent, fearing I’d find out later and be hurt. She might think, *I told him upfront, so he can’t say I hid it.* Her “closure” angle is genuine, but it’s also a shield. She’s likely terrified I’ll judge her for still having contact, so she’s minimizing it—*It’s just a few messages! We’re just friends now!—*to preempt conflict.  

Her attachment issues mean she might view this as a necessary step to move forward, even if it risks destabilizing us. She could be rationalizing the texting as healthy, but deep down, she might be craving validation from someone who understands her past. There’s a fear, too—maybe she’s worried that if she doesn’t “finish” things with the ex, she’ll always look back with regret.  

Her tone was casual because she’s trying to deflect tension. She might not realize how much this unsettles me because she’s used to prioritizing her needs over others’. She might feel guilty for making me uncomfortable but also resentful if I challenge her actions, thinking I’m undermining her growth. She’s caught between wanting to heal and wanting to keep me happy, but she’s unsure how to reconcile those things.  

There’s also a chance she’s already stopped texting but hasn’t processed it yet, or maybe the closure took longer than she thought. She might believe that once the closure is “done,” it won’t affect us—but she hasn’t checked in to see if that’s true. Her perspective is probably: *This is about me, not us.* But the line between personal healing and relational trust is blurry here.  

She might also feel trapped between her ex’s role in her past and my role in her present. The fact that she brought it up at all suggests she cares about my feelings, but she’s approaching it from a place of self-focused resolution rather than collaborative communication.

# My response

*[I take a deep breath, gathering my thoughts before speaking softly.]*  

“Hey, can we talk? I’ve been thinking a lot about when you mentioned texting your ex, and I want to be honest about how it’s affecting me.”  

*[I pause, choosing my words carefully to avoid blame.]*  

“I told you it was fine, and I didn’t want to make a scene, but… it’s been on my mind a lot. I’m trying not to overreact, but part of me feels… left out of the picture. You know I understand you need closure, but the idea that you’re still in contact with someone who was such a big part of your life—it makes me wonder where I fit into that process.”  

*[I lean forward, voice steady but vulnerable.]*  

“I’m not trying to police you or sound possessive. But… can you tell me more about what you’re going through? What’s the closure actually about? Is this still ongoing? I just… I want to support you, but I also need to feel like I’m part of the solution, not the problem.”  

*[Silence for a moment, giving her space to process.]*  

“I’m scared this isn’t just closure for you. Maybe it’s not, and that’s okay—I just need us to be honest with each other. I don’t want to assume the worst, but I need to know where this stands. Are you still talking to him? How do you feel about it now?”  

*[Ending with openness.]*  

“I’m saying this because I care. I don’t want this to fester, but I also don’t want to push too hard. You know I’m trying to be understanding, but I need to feel like my feelings matter here too.”  

This approach prioritizes honesty without aggression. It acknowledges her need for closure while asserting my right to be part of the conversation. By framing it as a request for clarity rather than an accusation, I’m aiming to reduce defensiveness. It also leaves room for her to explain her perspective, reinforcing that I’m open to understanding her side but need more information to feel secure. The key is balancing empathy for her struggles with assertiveness about my own emotional needs.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This defensive reaction feels like a punch to the gut. I thought I was being gentle, framing my concerns as a request for clarity, but she’s shut me down with accusations of distrust and jealousy. Part of me wants to retreat—*I’m the bad guy now?*—but another part is screaming that my feelings are valid. The irony cuts deep: I tried to avoid sounding jealous, but here we are.  

I’m spiraling into self-doubt. *Was I wrong to bring it up?* Maybe I should’ve stayed silent, but then what’s the point of honesty? Now I’m stuck between guilt for “overstepping” and frustration that my unease is dismissed as insecurity. I keep thinking of the times she’s told me about her past struggles—how her ex gaslit her, how she needed closure to move on. I wanted to support those efforts, but this feels different: it’s active contact, not just processing emotions.  

The jealousy she called out? Yeah, I admitted I felt it, but it’s not just about possessiveness. It’s the visceral fear that someone else gets to occupy space she once shared with me. That her past could still feel more urgent, more real, than our present. I hate that I’m jealous, but I can’t ignore the knot in my chest when I imagine her talking to him.  

Now I’m also angry at myself for not being “strong enough” to let it go. She’s right—I have to trust her. But trust isn’t a switch; it’s built through consistency. Did she think telling me once was enough? Or is the texting still happening? The lack of clarity is eating at me.  

Underneath it all is loneliness. I want to be the person she turns to for closure, not a placeholder while she finishes things with someone else. I need to feel like my voice matters, but now I’m second-guessing if I even have one in this conversation.  

The worst part is the powerlessness. I can’t force her to share more, but I also can’t silence my fear of being sidelined. I’m terrified this will fester into resentment, but I don’t know how to fix it without making her feel attacked again.  

---

# They're thinking & feeling

Her defensiveness isn’t just about the texting—it’s a reflex to protect her vulnerabilities. She’s been hurt before, and when someone questions her past, it triggers the fear that you’ll judge her or leave her. She hears criticism where there isn’t any, because that’s what her ex did. The accusation of distrust isn’t baseless; she knows she’s been transparent, so your hesitation feels like a betrayal of that.  

She’s also scrambling to defend her autonomy. To her, seeking closure is about healing, not about you. She might feel you’re inserting yourself into her internal process, making it about your needs instead of hers. The word “jealousy” is a shield—a way to deflect deeper insecurities: *If you’re jealous, then it’s your problem, not mine.*  

There’s guilt layered in there too. She might know the texting bothers you but is avoiding the guilt of letting you down. She wants to believe this isn’t a big deal, so she fights against the idea that it could be. Her past taught her that showing weakness or doubt leads to abandonment, so she doubles down on confidence even when she’s unsure.  

She’s terrified you’ll pull away if she admits things are messy. Maybe she’s already minimized the texting’s significance to herself, too. To acknowledge it might mean admitting she’s struggling, which feels dangerous. She wants to believe she’s doing the right thing, so she focuses on your “jealousy” as the problem—not the situation itself.  

Deep down, she might crave reassurance that you’ll still be there even if she’s not “fixed.” But she’s too scared to ask for it.  

---

# My response

*[I exhale slowly, trying to let the defensiveness melt away before speaking.]*  

“I hear what you’re saying. I’m not trying to control you or question your healing—that’s yours to navigate. I just… wanted to be honest about how this feels for me. You’re right, some of it is jealousy. I don’t like that, but I can’t ignore it either. I’m trying to work through that, but I need you to know it’s not about disbelieving you or your process.”  

*[I pause, choosing my words carefully.]*  

“There’s a difference between you needing space to heal and me feeling like I’m being excluded from something that affects us. I’m not asking you to stop what you’re doing or to explain yourself endlessly. But… I need to feel like my feelings aren’t automatically invalid just because they’re uncomfortable. Can we agree that this is a conversation we can revisit when neither of us is angry?”  

*[Softening my tone.]*  

“I don’t want to fight about this. I want us to figure it out together, but I can’t just pretend it doesn’t matter. I’m sorry if I came off pushy. Maybe we both need some time to think. Deal?”  

*[Leaning back, giving her space.]*  

“I care about you, and I’m not walking away. But I also need to feel like my voice isn’t erased here. Okay?”  

This response avoids doubling down on blame or defensiveness. It validates her perspective while gently asserting my own boundaries. By offering to pause the conversation and revisit it later, I’m reducing pressure, which might help her feel less cornered. The key is separating the issue from my character—*I’m jealous, but I’m also trying to grow*. It leaves room for her to reflect without feeling interrogated, while making clear that my unease isn’t going away on its own.
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
